title: Glencore Scraps Plan to Move Primary Listing to New York
description: Glencore Plc scrapped plans to move its primary listing away from London and reported a fall in its first-half profits, weighed down by weak prices for some of its most important products. Alon Olsha on Bloomberg Intelligence has more on Bloomberg Television. (Source: Bloomberg)
content: Walk us through why they're saying that moving their listing is not accretive anymore. Well, it was always going to be a pretty tough case to make moving the listing, but the temptation was there. I mean, it was really born out of the frustration management had with the coal portfolio, the coal heavy portfolio that they have not being appreciated by more ESG minded European investors and the US investors tend to be less ESG focused, particularly in the current climate. There are listed publicly listed coal companies there already. So the thinking was it could potentially drive a rerating, but the move was always fraught with risk. Firstly, significant friction costs moving to listing, but more importantly was indexation. There was no guarantee that Glencore would leave the Footsie and then into one of the big US indices. So it could end up actually harming the valuation instead of benefiting it. The other highlight from the Glencore earnings is the fact that we haven't necessarily seen any clarity on where this $1 billion of cost cutting is coming from. They announced this last week. It coincided with them raising their long term profit forecast. But what do you what do you think could be the winners and losers in terms of them cutting costs? Yeah, well, they've mentioned a few things, but you're right, they haven't been completely clear. There will be some staff reductions. They have consolidated the nickel and zinc units into one unit and it will be a lot of pressure on them to deliver these cost savings in the second half because this was a pretty weak first half. It's the weakest first half they've posted in five years. So there's a lot resting on the second half of the year. They need to ramp up copper output in particular and pretty aggressively and reduce costs there. And they need to deliver these cost savings to satisfy the market.
summary: Glencore has decided to abandon its plan to move its primary listing to New York, citing that it was not accretive anymore due to concerns about the company's coal portfolio not being appreciated by European investors and US investors. The move was seen as a risk due to significant friction costs and indexation issues, as there was no guarantee that Glencore would be included in one of the big US indices. The decision was made out of frustration over their coal portfolio and concerns about their exposure to less ESG-focused European investors. However, the move could potentially harm the valuation rather than benefit it. The announcement of the $1 billion cost cutting coincided with a rise in their long term profit forecast and a focus on increasing copper output and reducing costs for the second half of the year.
shortSummary: Glencore Scraps plan to move its primary listing to New York due to high costs and market risks, despite potential upside down due to coal portfolio underperformance.
argos_summary: Glencore's management has decided against moving their listing due to concerns about the potential negative impact on valuation and the risks associated with indexation. The company is facing challenges with its coal-heavy portfolio, which is not favored by ESG-focused investors, and has announced a $1 billion cost-cutting initiative without clear details on its implementation. The need for significant improvements in copper output and cost reductions is critical, especially following a weak first half of the year.
